--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Kevin Klinemeier <zipwow@y...> wrote:
> Hey, I just wanted to chime in with this bit of wisdom that took me a
> long time to get right:
> 
> MockObjects do none of the actual work of their parents.

Yes, that is a crutial point.  Some people create mocks by
subclassing.  I disagree with that approach as it leaves to open to
undesired "real" behaviour leaking into the mock.  My approach is to
use (first extracting as required) an interface for the behaviour to
be mocked.  Then the mock is completely standalone.  This was
originally a requirement for EasyMock, but I understand that
recent/upcoming versions  don't have that requirement.

This is also a major benefit of using a Mock.  Not only does it let
you verify that the code under test is using the mocked object as
expected/required, but it replaces the real object (e.g. network,
database, etc.) lettin you isolate the code that the test is concerned
with.

Dave
